item.title: I dont get the number at the end of a command.subString
item.dc:creator: @LearningToCode LearningToCode
item.description:
@LearningToCode wrote:

Hey thanks that has help alot hank you
just 1 thing… is this code right? :
else if(command.startsWith(“pickup”)&&playerRights>=2){
try{
int newItemID = Integer.parseInt(command.substring(7, 11));
int newItemAmount = Integer.parseInt(command.substring(11));
if( /*newItemID <= 7954 && */newItemID >= 0){
addItem(newItemID, newItemAmount);
}
else{
sendMessage(“No such item.”);
}
}
catch(Exception e){
sendMessage(“Wrong Syntax! Use as ::pickup 0995 10”);
}
}

I abit unsure abot the (11)
i looked around and many people have 12… but for me i tried counting it and find it as 11… or can’t i count?
Please and Thank you again =)

item.source: I dont get the number at the end of a command.subString

item.title: I dont get the number at the end of a command.subString
item.dc:creator: @Frell Frell
item.description:
@Frell wrote:

DOKS R UR FREND

iirc if you had a string that was “dog” and you did command.substring(2); it would start 2 characters in (or 1 depending on if it starts at 0) so it would outprint “g”

so:
command.substring(2);
“cat” - “t”
“poodle” - “odle”
“antidisestablishmentarianism” - “tidisestablishmentarianism”

But in your case it sounds like its getting it from something like this:
value: 1234

"value: " is 7 chars, and you’re reading inwards 7 chars so it would start at the char after the space, which would give you “1234” and then ofc you’re turning it into an int etc.

i got time till i go night night so if you didnt get that ill explain a bit more

"value: "
if you count those letters (count the space to) you get 7.
since you’re doing substring(7);, the space is where it would start from.
so
“value: 1”
is 8 chars, but its been told to start reading at 7, so it outprints the 8th char and above. And the 8th char is “1”, so it would outprint “1” and any numbers/letters after 1

IDK hard to explain at 8am when you’ve been up all night for no reason.

Read full topic

Integer.parseInt(command.substring(7, 11));

What do the “(7,11)” refer to???

Also:
int newItemAmount = Integer.parseInt(command.substring(12));

Again whats the number in brackets at the end doing???

Please help, I am new =)
